Subjective: Right-sided low back pain for 1.5 weeks, progressively worsening. Radiates down posterior and lateral right leg to foot. Constant, severe pain. Associated tingling and dull sensation on outer right lower leg. Started after lifting heavy items. Max dose Paracetamol/Ibuprofen ineffective. Unable to sleep or work due to pain. No subjective leg weakness, no saddle anesthesia, no bowel/bladder changes. Social: Works in a supermarket. Request: Wants pain relief; concerned about needing surgery; asks about necessity of a scan.
Objective: General: Obvious pain with movement. Back Exam: No visible deformity. No vertebral tenderness. Tenderness over right gluteal region. Neuro Exam LE: Sensation dull on right leg/foot compared to left. Motor strength 5/5 and symmetric throughout, though movement is painful on right. Reflexes 2+ and symmetric. Straight Leg Raise: Positive on right, negative on left.
Assessment: Right lumbosacral radiculopathy, secondary to suspected herniated disc. No clinical signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Explained diagnosis of suspected hernia and conservative management approach.
2. Start Pregabalin for neuropathic pain. Counselled on slow dose titration and potential side effects.
3. Advised no driving for at least 1 week after starting or increasing dose.
4. Referral to Physiotherapy for guided exercises.
5. Safety Netting: Return immediately for new saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder incontinence, or profound leg weakness.
6. Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to review pain control and medication tolerance.
